Title:
Polyphasic Identification Employing Phylogenetic and
Taxonomic Analyses on Three New Wood-inhabiting Fungi of Xylodon
(Basidiomycota) in Forest Ecological System
Keywords:
biodiversity; ecology; environment; molecular systematics;
white-rot fungi; Yunnan-Guizhou Plateau
Abstract:
Wood- inhabiting fungi are a cosmopolitan group and they
have a rich diversity on the basis of growing on boreal, temperate,
subtropical, and tropical vegetations. Three wood-inhabiting fungal
species, Xylodon grandineus, X. punctus, and X. wenshanensis spp. nov.,
were collected from southern China, here proposed as new taxa based on a
combination of morphological features and molecular evidence. Xylodon
grandineus is characterized by the coriaceous basidiomata with
grandinioid hymenial surface and ellipsoid basidiospores; X. punctus is
characterized by the membranous hymenophore and smooth hymenial surface
with speckled distribution, cystidia absent; and X. wenshanensis is
characterized by its grandinioid with cream to slightly buff hymenial
surface and cystidia of two types. Sequences of ITS and nLSU rRNA
markers of the studied samples were generated, and phylogenetic analyses
were performed with maximum likelihood, maximum parsimony, and Bayesian
inference methods. The ITS+nLSU analysis of the order Hymenochaetales
indicated that at the generic level, after a series of phylogenetic
studies, six genera, viz.Â Fasciodontia, Hastodontia, Hyphodontia,
Lyomyces, Kneiffiella and Xylodon were eventually accepted to
accommodate the members of Hyphodontia sensu lato; based on further
analysis of ITS dataset, X. grandineus was a sister to X. nesporii; X.
punctus formed a monophyletic lineage and then grouped with X.
filicinus, X. hastifer, X. hyphodontinus and X. tropicus; while X.
wenshanensis was retrieved as a sister to X. xinpingensis.
